thread.title: Treasury yields climb on strong U.S. data, Chinese stimulus - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Treasury yields climb on strong U.S. data, Chinese stimulus - MarketWatch

author: Ellie Ismailidou
title: Treasury yields climb on strong U.S. data, Chinese stimulus - MarketWatch
text:
Treasury yields continued to climb on Wednesday, as new easing efforts from China’s central bank along with stronger-than-expected economic boosted expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later this year.
While Wall Street rallied at the open , investors sold bonds. The 10-year Treasury yield climbed to its highest point in more than a week, after posting its largest one-day increase in two years on Tuesday.
The 10-year yield TMUBMUSD10Y, +3.34% has swung widely in recent days, dropping on Monday to its lowest point in nearly four months and then climbing on Tuesday.
On Wednesday, the 10-year yield was up 2.6 basis points to 2.161%, trading slightly above its 200-day moving average of 2.12% , according to data from CRT Capital.
The next yield level that traders are looking at is the 40-day moving average of 2.24%. “[That] seems doable, given the overbought momentum,” David Ader, head of government bond strategy at CRT Capital Group, said in a note.
Among other maturities, the yield on the two-year note TMUBMUSD02Y, +9.21% gained 3.9 basis points to 0.680% and the 30-year yield TMUBMUSD30Y, +2.78% rose three basis points to 2.883%.
On Wednesday, a report showed orders for durable or long-lasting U.S. goods rose 2% in July , ahead of a revised reading of second-quarter gross domestic product growth, expected Thursday morning.
“The report is a sign that domestic business optimism is relatively high. But the U.S. economy still faces the headwinds of the strong dollar and China’s economic slowdown,” said Ninh Chung, investment strategist at SVB Asset Management.
After trading ended in China on Wednesday, the People’s Bank of China said it will inject $21.80 billion into the financial system in a new easing effort . That follows the central bank’s interest-rate cut on Tuesday, which initially helped give a lift to the U.S. stock market before a sharp reversal in the late afternoon that left key indexes with their sixth straight loss.
Read : The corporate bond market foreshadowed a stock-market rout
The upbeat economic data along with the stock market’s slow recovery have refocused the market’s attention to a potential interest-rate increase in September or October. According to the CME Group FedWatch tool that tracks Fed funds futures prices, the market-implied rate-hike probability was 24% for September and 34% for October on Wednesday.
“The Fed would still need to see the equity market recover its losses before being comfortable to act,” said Jennifer Vail, head of fixed income at U.S. Bank Wealth Management.
In Europe government bond yields moved lower, as stock markets were under pressure and investors bought safe assets, primarily government bonds. The yield on the benchmark German 10-year bund TMBMKDE-10Y, -1.39% declined by 3.4 basis points to 0.711% after gaining 16.4 basis points on Tuesday. The yield has gained over 63 basis points since April 20, when it reached its all-time low at 0.073%.
